questions.text: While prescribing the conventional H1 antihistaminics the patient should be advised to avoid
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Driving motor vehicles
Explanation:
Conventional (1st generation) H1-antihistamines (e.g., diphenhydramine, chlorpheniramine) are centrally acting and cross the blood-brain barrier, causing sedation and drowsiness. This makes activities like driving dangerous.
• Processed cheese → MAOI interaction concern, not with antihistamines
• Stress/Physical exertion → not directly contraindicated

questions.text: A 68-year-old man has recently been diagnosed with hypertension and started on monotherapy designed to reduce peripheral resistance and prevent sodium and water retention. Since commencing treatment he has developed a persistent cough. Which of the following drugs would have the same benefits but would not cause the cough?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Losartan
Explanation:
The patient is likely on an ACE inhibitor (e.g., Lisinopril) which causes dry cough due to bradykinin accumulation.
Losartan is an ARB (Angiotensin II receptor blocker) and does not increase bradykinin, hence no cough, while retaining similar hemodynamic benefits.
• Prazosin → α-blocker, not similar effect
• Propranolol → β-blocker, not first-line for elderly HTN

choices.text: Unpredictable, inherent, qualitatively abnormal reaction of a drug

questions.text: Idiosyncrasy reaction of a drug is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Unpredictable, inherent, qualitatively abnormal reaction of a drug
Explanation:
Idiosyncratic reactions are genetically determined abnormal responses to drugs, unrelated to dose or known pharmacology.
Example: Hemolysis with primaquine in G6PD deficiency

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman recently diagnosed with gouty arthritis started a treatment with a drug that inhibits leukocyte migration and phagocytosis secondary to inhibition of tubulin polymerization. Which of the following drugs did the patient most likely take?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Colchicine
Explanation:
Colchicine disrupts microtubules by inhibiting tubulin polymerization, reducing neutrophil migration and inflammation. Used in acute gout attacks.
• Allopurinol → xanthine oxidase inhibitor (chronic gout)
• Prednisone → steroid
• Probenecid → uricosuric

choices.text: Rifampicin increases the failure rate of barrier contraception

questions.text: Which of the following statements about CYP interaction is true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Phenytoin causes HRT failure
Explanation:
Phenytoin is a potent CYP450 inducer, increasing metabolism of estrogen/progestin → HRT/OCP failure.
• Rifampicin also induces → barrier method unaffected
• Smokers → faster theophylline metabolism → ↓ toxicity
• Isoniazid → inhibitor, not related to OCP

choices.text: Iron is absorbed in ferrous form and it’s absorption is more with concurrent use of vitamin C
Iron absorption is inhibited by tannic acid
Best time to take iron is after meals to avoid gastric discomfort

questions.text: Luminal effect: All are true except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Phytates increase iron absorption
Explanation:
Phytates (in cereals) form complexes with iron and reduce its absorption.
• Vitamin C enhances absorption
• Tannic acid (tea) inhibits
• Iron best taken empty stomach (but after meals to avoid discomfort)

questions.text: This drug inhibits/slows the digestion of sugars in the digestive tract when given with meals, used for DM type 1 & 2 both for treatment of postprandial hyperglycemia-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Alpha-glucosidase inhibitor
Explanation:
Acarbose, Miglitol inhibit alpha-glucosidase in intestinal brush border → delays carbohydrate digestion → ↓ postprandial glucose spike.
• Biguanides → ↓ hepatic glucose production
• Orlistat → anti-obesity (lipase inhibitor)

questions.text: Currently used DPP IV inhibitor, safe in kidney disease patients is/are:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Linagliptin
Explanation:
Most DPP-4 inhibitors (e.g., sitagliptin) require dose adjustment in renal failure, except linagliptin, which is hepatically cleared.
• Metformin → contraindicated in renal dysfunction (lactic acidosis risk)
• Glyburide → risk of hypoglycemia in CKD

questions.text: Which of the following drugs does recommend as first line therapy for overweight patients with type 2 diabetes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Semaglutide
Explanation:
Semaglutide, a GLP-1 agonist, causes weight loss, improves glycemic control, and has cardioprotective effects. Preferred in overweight/obese patients.
• SGLT2 inhibitors (Empagliflozin) also good, but GLP-1 superior for weight loss.
• Gliclazide (sulfonylurea) causes weight gain
• Sitagliptin is weight-neutral

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman was brought to the emergency department because of serious breathing difficulty. Two hours earlier, she had taken a drug for a headache. The patient had been suffering from sinusitis and nasal polyps for 6 months. Physical examination showed severe bronchospasm. Which of the following drugs most likely caused the patient’s signs and symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Acetylsalicylic acid
Explanation:
This is aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD) or Samter’s triad:
• Asthma
• Nasal polyps
• Aspirin sensitivity → bronchospasm due to leukotriene excess
• Sumatriptan & ergotamine act on serotonin; not the culprit here

questions.text: Which of the following agent is DOC for NSAID induced gastric ulcer-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Lansoperazole           
Explanation:
• Lansoprazole is best for general ulcers and superior to misoprostol for NSAID-induced peptic ulcer.
• Misoprostol is a PGE1 analogue that increases gastric mucus and bicarbonate secretion and reduces acid secretion—protective against NSAID-induced ulcers.
• Megaldrate → antacid
• Ranitidine → outdated, withdrawn in many places

questions.text: Tolerance develops to all of the following action of opioids except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Constipation
Explanation:
Opioid tolerance develops to most effects (analgesia, euphoria, nausea), but not to constipation or miosis.
• Constipation is due to reduced GI motility → persists chronically

questions.text: A pregnant lady was given indomethacin in 26 weeks to treat arthritic pain. It could lead to?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Premature closure of ductus arteriosus
Explanation:
Indomethacin inhibits prostaglandin synthesis, which keeps the ductus arteriosus open in utero. Risk of premature closure leads to pulmonary hypertension in fetus.
• PDA closure is desired postnatally (not prenatally)
• Not related to ductus venosus or foramen ovale

questions.text: The antithrombotic drug which inhibits P2Y12 irreversibly is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Prasugrel
Explanation:
Prasugrel (like clopidogrel) irreversibly inhibits P2Y12 ADP receptor on platelets → prevents aggregation.
• Ticagrelor is reversible
• Aspirin works via COX inhibition
• Tranexamic acid is an antifibrinolytic, not antiplatelet

questions.text: We have two patients. One requires suppression of emesis caused by an anticancer drug that causes a high incidence and severity of vomiting (highly emetogenic drug). Another patient has severe diabetic gastroparesis and gastro-oesophageal reflux, which requires relief. Which one drug would be suitable for both indications (assuming no specific contraindications)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Metoclopramide
Explanation:
Metoclopramide is a D2 antagonist:
• Central effect: antiemetic
• Peripheral effect: prokinetic → helps gastroparesis, GERD
• Ondansetron: only antiemetic, no prokinetic action
• Dronabinol not used for gastroparesis

questions.text: A patient is being treated with sulfasalazine. The most likely purpose for giving it is for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Inflammatory bowel disease
Explanation:
Sulfasalazine is used in ulcerative colitis and Crohn’s. It releases 5-ASA (mesalamine) in the colon to reduce inflammation.
• Not used for C. diff, E. coli, or H. pylori

choices.text: They are metabolized slowly and have longer duration of action

questions.text: Low molecular weight heparins differ from unfractionated heparin in that:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

All of the above
Explanation:
• LMWH inhibits Xa > IIa, has predictable pharmacokinetics, longer t½ → fixed dosing
• Unfractionated needs monitoring (aPTT), variable effect

questions.text: All of the following hormones have cell surface receptors except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Thyroxine
Explanation:
• Thyroxine (T3/T4) → enters cells → acts via nuclear receptors
• Adrenaline, GH, insulin → membrane-bound receptors

questions.text: Sodium hydrogen carbonate is sold as a drug under various names such as alkali, baking soda, uracol, and sodium bicarbonate. Which of the following is considered a proprietary name for this substance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Uracol
Explanation:
Uracol is a brand name (proprietary). Others are generic or chemical names.

questions.text: Which of the following ingredients has neither specific antitussive nor expectorant, nor bronchodilator action, but is commonly present in proprietary cough formulations:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Chlorpheniramine
Explanation:
Chlorpheniramine is an H1 antihistamine (often added for allergy), but has no direct cough relief action.
• Guaifenesin → expectorant
• Noscapine → antitussive
• Ambroxol → mucolytic/expectorant

questions.text: Least teratogenic antiepileptic drug in pregnancy is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Levetiracetam
Explanation:
Among antiepileptics:
• Valproate → neural tube defects
• Carbamazepine, phenytoin → craniofacial defects
• Lamotrigine has low risk with low teratogenicity
• Levetiracetam has lowest risk, often used in pregnancy

questions.text: Which of the following is an oral anticoagulant?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Dabigatran
Explanation:
• Dabigatran is an oral direct thrombin (IIa) inhibitor
• Heparin, Fondaparinux, Bivalirudin → all parenteral anticoagulants

questions.text: Which of the following is an inhibitor of the intestinal mucosal transporter NPC1L1, responsible for the absorption of dietary and biliary cholesterol?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Ezetimibe
Explanation:
• NPC1L1 is a transporter for cholesterol uptake in gut
• Ezetimibe blocks this → ↓ cholesterol absorption
• Statins (e.g., atorvastatin) ↓ cholesterol synthesis, not absorption

questions.text: A 60 years old asthmatic man comes in for a checkup and complains that he is having some difficulty in starting to urinate. Physical examination indicates that the man has a blood pressure of 160/100 mm of Hg and has lightly enlarge prostate. Which of the following medications would be useful in treating both of these conditions:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Terazosin
Explanation:
• Terazosin is an α1-blocker → relaxes prostatic smooth muscle and also lowers BP
• Amlodipine: ↓ BP but worsens BPH (edema)
• Phentolamine: non-selective α-blocker, not ideal
• Isoproterenol: β-agonist, not used for either

questions.text: A 68 years old man presents to the emergency department with acute heart failure after MI attack. You decide that this patient requires immediate drug therapy to improve his cardiac function. Which one of the following drugs would be most beneficial?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Dobutamine
Explanation:
• Dobutamine is a β1-selective agonist → ↑ inotropy without much ↑ HR or vasoconstriction
• Useful in cardiogenic shock or post-MI acute HF
• Epinephrine and norepinephrine may cause arrhythmias or vasoconstriction

questions.text: Which combination of seizures and it is first line treatment drug is false?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Myoclonic seizures: Topiramate
Explanation:
• Valproate is first-line for myoclonic seizures
• Topiramate is used second-line
• Rest are correct:
o Absence → Ethosuximide
o Focal → Levetiracetam
o Generalized → Valproate

questions.text: Tekchand, a farmer comes to you in the emergency in comatose state. Patient had profuse sweating and lacrimation diarrhea and urination were apparent. On examination pupil was constricted and BP of the farmer was 80/60 mmHg. You make a diagnosis of anticholinesterase poisoning you decided to administer him atropine. All of the following actions will be reversed by atropine EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Muscle paralysis
Explanation:
• Atropine blocks muscarinic receptors, but not nicotinic receptors
• So it does not reverse muscle paralysis (NMJ effect) → needs pralidoxime
• Reverses: bronchoconstriction, bradycardia, secretions

questions.text: An elderly woman, who is a chronic smoker, diagnosed with lung cancer has abnormally low serum osmolality and hyponatremia. Which of the following drug is used to treat this:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Tolvaptan
Explanation:
• SIADH → hyponatremia due to excess ADH
• Tolvaptan is a vasopressin V2 antagonist → ↑ free water excretion
• Furosemide helps but not specific
• Terlipressin is a vasoconstrictor, not used
• Amiloride is potassium-sparing diuretic

questions.text: A female presented with pain and redness in her great toe. Serum uric acid level was 9.7 mg/dl. Apart from analgesic, one more drug was prescribed to her that decreases the formation of uric acid. Which enzyme is likely to be inhibited by this drug:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Xanthine oxidase
Explanation:
• Allopurinol, febuxostat inhibit xanthine oxidase, which converts xanthine → uric acid
• ↓ uric acid formation → chronic gout management
• Other enzymes listed not involved in uric acid metabolism

questions.text: Drugs used for chemo induced nausea and vomiting?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Granisetron + Dexamethasone + Aprepitant
Explanation:
This triple therapy covers:
• 5-HT3 antagonist (granisetron) → acute emesis
• Steroid (dexamethasone)
• NK1 receptor antagonist (aprepitant) → delayed CINV
• Most effective for highly emetogenic chemotherapy

questions.text: Patient underwent surgery and during recovery he was shouting and having hallucinations. Which anaesthetic drug was used?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Ketamine
Explanation:
• Ketamine is a dissociative anesthetic acting via NMDA antagonism
• Post-op emergence reactions: hallucinations, nightmares, delirium are classic
• Others:
o Propofol → smooth recovery
o Etomidate → no hallucinations
o Halothane → hepatotoxicity risk, no dissociation

questions.text: A female came to general OPD with pain & inflammation of many joints. After examination & further investigations was diagnosed as rheumatoid arthritis.  Doctor prescribed methotrexate for this. Which of the following is mechanism of action in this drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

DHFRase inhibitor
Explanation:
• Methotrexate inhibits dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR) → ↓ purine synthesis → ↓ lymphocyte proliferation
• Also increases adenosine → anti-inflammatory
• Other options:
o Xanthine oxidase → allopurinol
o Thymidylate synthase → 5-FU
o Ribonucleotide synthetase → incorrect

questions.text: An elderly patient came with features of Parkinsonism like rigidity, hypokinesia etc. Which of the following is not prescribed to this patient:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Donepezil
Explanation:
• Donepezil is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used in Alzheimer’s disease
• Parkinson's drugs:
o Levodopa + carbidopa (dopaminergic)
o Ropinirole (D2 agonist)
o Safinamide (MAO-B inhibitor)

questions.text: A patient of pancreatic carcinoma. You gave morphine for relieving pain. After few days, the pain is not relieved as relieved earlier. Why?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Desensitization of opioid receptor
Explanation:
• Chronic use → tolerance due to receptor desensitization/downregulation
• Not due to ↑ pain or ↓ absorption
• Upregulation is not typical with opioids

questions.text: A patient suffering for rectal carcinoma and on chemotherapy drugs develops severe profuse diarrhea. Which of the flowing drug should start first to control this diarrhea:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Loperamide
Explanation:
• Loperamide is first-line for chemo-induced diarrhea
• Octreotide used in severe refractory cases or carcinoid
• Atropine → used with irinotecan (for early diarrhea)
• Ofloxacin → used if infection suspected

questions.text: A 68 year old male cancer patient on chemotherapy developed neutropenia. Which of the following drug is used to increase the immunity in this person?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Filgrastim
Explanation:
• Filgrastim is G-CSF → stimulates neutrophil production
• Darbepoetin → RBC stimulation
• Oprelvekin → platelets (IL-11)
• Iron dextran → anemia, not WBC

questions.text: A 38 yr old college professor suffering from depression comes to you with complaints of unable to get involved in process of intercourse with his wife. Which of the following anti depressant is best to be prescribed to him:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Bupropion
Explanation:
• Bupropion (NDRI) → minimal/no sexual side effects
• SSRIs like escitalopram, venlafaxine → sexual dysfunction common
• Imipramine → anticholinergic, sedating, not preferred

questions.text: Which of the following drug used for pain relief in arthritis acts by both opioid and non opioid mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Tramadol
Explanation:
• Tramadol is weak μ-opioid agonist + inhibits serotonin & norepinephrine reuptake
• Useful in neuropathic & moderate pain
• Paracetamol: non-opioid
• Diclofenac, Ketorolac: NSAIDs only

questions.text: After taking some drug for acute attack of migraine a patient developed nausea and vomiting. He also developed tingling and numbness in the tip of the most finger that also turned blue. Which of the following us the most likely implicated in causing the above finding
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Dihydroergotamine
Explanation:
• Dihydroergotamine causes vasoconstriction → can lead to ischemia of digits (ergotism)
• Sumatriptan also vasoconstrictive, but less severe
• Morphine, aspirin → no such effect

questions.text: Chronic alcoholic suddenly stops drinking and getting is in Delirium. Best management is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Lorazepam + thiamine
Explanation:
• Lorazepam (benzodiazepine) is first-line for DT
• Thiamine prevents Wernicke's encephalopathy
• Haloperidol used only for severe agitation, not as monotherapy

questions.text: Which of the following would be safe to give in patients with a severe penicillin allergy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Azithromycin
Explanation:
• Azithromycin (macrolide) is safe in penicillin-allergic patients.
• Cephalosporins (e.g., cefalexin) can have cross-reactivity (especially 1st-gen)
• Flucloxacillin, Co-Amoxiclav → β-lactams → avoid in allergy

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT true regarding macrolide antibiotics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Vancomycin
Explanation:
• Vancomycin is not a macrolide, it's a glycopeptide.
• Macrolides (like erythromycin) →
o Inhibit 50S ribosomal subunit
o Block peptidyl transferase → inhibit elongation
o Can cause QT prolongation

questions.text: A patient having lung disorder, which of the following anticancer should not be given to this patient
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Bleomycin
Explanation:
• Bleomycin causes pulmonary fibrosis
• Avoid in patients with preexisting lung disease
• Others like vincristine, adriamycin (cardiotoxic), mitomycin → not lung-specific

questions.text: An AIDS patient, who is being treated with multiple drugs, develops breast hypertrophy, central adiposity, hyperlipidemia, insulin resistance and nephrolithiasis. If these changes are related to his drug treatment, this drug belongs to which group of anti-retroviral drugs?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Protease inhibitors
Explanation:
• Protease inhibitors → classic metabolic side effects:
o Lipodystrophy
o Hyperlipidemia, insulin resistance
o Gynecomastia
• NRTIs and NNRTIs less associated

questions.text: In a patient with culture-positive enterococcal endocarditis who has failed to respond to vancomycin because of resistance, the treatment most likely to be effective is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Linezolid
Explanation:
• Linezolid is active against VRE (vancomycin-resistant enterococci)
• Other options (macrolides, tetracyclines) are ineffective for resistant enterococci

questions.text: A 30 year old male with known TB infection and taking medication since 1 month comes to the Eye OPD with complaint of visual disturbances including decreased visibility and slight color blindness. If these symptoms are due to his drug treatment, which one of the following drugs is most likely the cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ethambutol
Explanation:
• Ethambutol → dose-dependent optic neuritis
o ↓ visual acuity
o Red-green color blindness
• Rifampicin → orange urine
• Isoniazid → peripheral neuropathy
• Ciprofloxacin → not in TB standard regimen

questions.text: A patient with watery stools is diagnosed as suffering from amebic dysentery. He is given a drug that causes a metalic taste in the mouth and was advised not to drink alcohol. Which drug may be given?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Metronidazole
Explanation:
• Metronidazole:
o Metallic taste
o Disulfiram-like reaction with alcohol
• Others (iodoquinol, emetine, diloxanide) lack these effects

questions.text: Which of the following is a drug that interferes with the process of DNA production in the virus that causes genital herpes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Acyclovir
Explanation:
• Acyclovir is a nucleoside analog activated by viral thymidine kinase
o Inhibits viral DNA polymerase
• Amantadine → influenza
• Vancomycin → bacterial
• Erythromycin → protein synthesis

questions.text: Which of the following drug can be used to manage hematemesis caused by infusion of streptokinase for the management of MI?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Tranexamic acid
Explanation:
• Tranexamic acid → antifibrinolytic
o Inhibits plasminogen activation
o Useful in bleeding due to thrombolytics
• Vitamin K → for warfarin-induced bleeding
• Heparin, hirudin → anticoagulants (worsen bleeding)

questions.text: A young male patient was suffering from AML so Doxorubicin based regimen chemotherapy given for treated. After some time he is having swelling in lower limb and breathlessness on excretion & during night time. Which is the possible toxicity to this patient
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Dilated cardiomyopathy
Explanation:
• Doxorubicin → dose-dependent cardiotoxicity
o Causes dilated cardiomyopathy due to free radical damage
• Managed with dexrazoxane (cardioprotective)
• Hypertrophic or restrictive CM are unrelated
